repnme.cdata!:
Peru - First and Second Programmatic Fiscal
            Management and Competitiveness Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First and Second
            Programmatic Fiscal Management and Competitiveness
            Development Policy Loan (FMCDPL) Project for Peru were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Grantee performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: when the global financial crisis
            erupted in September 2008 and the government asked the Bank
            for urgent financial support, the Bank was able to come
            through in record time. The capability to respond quickly to
            changing country and/or international conditions is
            essential for maintaining the relevance of the Bank and for
            its relationship with its clients, particularly with the
            middle-income countries. The design of the policy matrix
            balanced ambition and breadth with a focus on areas with
            strong government commitment. Striking such a balance at the
            beginning of the series is not an easy task. On the one
            hand, setting out to do only the reforms that are most
            likely to be achieved would make for a more satisfactory
            performance at the end of the program. On the other hand, it
            is most beneficial if the program can be used to push
            forward difficult reforms. While a small fraction of the
            outcomes in the FMCDPL program were not achieved, resulting
            in only satisfactory performance, the work that took place
            in the less successful areas had moved the agenda forward
            and prepared the ground for future reforms, which are being
            continued and implemented at this time.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Third Programmatic Fiscal Management
            and Competitiveness Development Policy Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
This Development Policy Loan (DPL) is
            the third in a programmatic series of four Fiscal Management
            and Competitiveness Development Policy Loans (FMCDPL). The
            FMCDPL series, along with parallel DPL in the areas of
            social policy and environment, were designed in close
            partnership with Government of Peru (GoP) and in line with
            its policy program, as outlined in the Country Partnership
            Strategy (CPS). The GoP stated a clear vision for: (i)
            building on recent economic successes to achieve higher
            growth and better social outcomes; (ii) constructing a
            better social contract between the government and citizens
            based on effective social development; and (iii) modernizing
            state institutions. This FMCDPL programmatic series has been
            prepared at the request of President Garcia's
            administration. It has been designed to support Peru's
            own program. Unlike the previous two loans in the series,
            this third operation includes policies to deal with
            short-term issues such the effects of the global crisis,
            while maintaining momentum in the implementation of reforms
            that address structural issues and which will have
            medium-term effects. The operation supports the GoP efforts
            in the context of a global economic slowdown. The
            development objective of the loan is to contribute to growth
            and poverty alleviation by supporting two main policy areas:
            (a) quality of fiscal management; and (b) competitiveness.
            Peru entered the global crisis in a solid position and has
            managed its challenges well. Good macroeconomic fundamentals
            and appropriate policy responses to the crisis moderate the
            negative impact of weaker external demand and external
            shocks. Aware of the downside risks to economic growth as
            well to poverty and employment, the GoP has implemented
            counter-cyclical policies to mitigate the impact of the
            crisis. Nonetheless, the GoP has not lost sight of the
            medium-term objectives of its reform agenda, and has
            continued to make progress in improving the effectiveness of
            fiscal management and supporting the country's
            competitiveness and integration into the global economy.
